Award.AwardTitle: Exploring the value of a digitized intervention on improving college readiness and interest in STEM for urban and rural secondary students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The EHR Core Research (ECR) program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that will generate foundational knowledge in the field. To that end, this project will extend the purpose of the College Ambition Program (CAP), a school-wide intervention designed to encourage high school students to become college applicants, particularly in STEM fields, and enroll in postsecondary school. The CAP will serve predominantly minority and low-income high school students and those with special needs in urban and rural areas where enrollment in postsecondary institutions is below the state average. While the CAP has been successful in raising postsecondary enrollment, a series of new digital experiences will be created and added to the program to further students' college readiness and increase their interest in STEM fields. CAP students will be provided opportunities to access a variety of playlists on a digitized platform that will monitor and rewards personalized learning. Tailored to students' interests and strengths, playlists will be designed to inspire motivation, advance college knowledge, and enhance particular skill sets. Students who successfully complete their playlists will earn a badge, which is a publicly shareable digital credential that will show evidence of a substantive learning outcome. Badges will entitle students to participate in STEM internships experiences in businesses and university programs that, when completed, will indicate a set of competencies that can positively impact their postsecondary acceptance when included on college applications.

Collaboratively developed with CAP personnel, businesses, and university partners, the playlists will be designed to ensure that the badges and internships will provide clear paths to higher education and careers. Consisting of a series of primers, the gamified playlists will enable students to: set goals; pace their learning activities; receive embedded feedback; and receive a tangible reward upon completion. Students will engage in unique, customized knowledge and skill-building learning experiences not typically found in high schools, but will be viewed as advantageous for admission and persistence in higher education. The social and emotional experiences students will have during these experiences will be measured using smartphone technology synced to a technological playlist/badge platform. Data retrieved from the smartphones will be analyzed using multivariate methods that account for multiple differences between students. This empirical evaluation of the effectiveness of the playlist experiences will allow for the collection of data to support the inclusion of technological tracking and strategic planning in programs that will improve college-going rates and enhance participation in STEM for underrepresented students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The contemporary 21st Century high schooler is technologically savvy and utilizes their knowledge to create digital identities, communities, and even realities.  It has been estimated that approximately ninety-five percent of youth own or have access to smartphones (Anderson & Jiang, 2018), which they use for a variety of different purposes such as communication, information, and entertainment. Unfortunately, many of these students in the U.S., specifically low-income, Minority, and first-generation students, tend to have inadequate academic preparation and an unrealistic understanding of the education and career opportunities for their future lives (Lowry, 2017). When the students? lack of resources is compounded with a scarcity of critical knowledge about potential college and career pathways, a misalignment of their college and career ambitions often result. (Perry et al., 2016). Building on two years of  National Science Foundation (NSF) support, (Award No. 1661236), our team sought to address this lack of college and career readiness by creating a mobile game prototype-?I2W? (I2W).

I2W employs a dynamic game design where students can envision and enact themselves in a diverse range of career and education pathways. Depending on the choices they make in the game, students can learn through how to translate that vision into action. The app was tested in urban and rural high schools to determine if playing the I2W mobile app had an effect on the changes of students? 4-year college plans, college-going aspirations and increases in those educational aspirations over the course of a school year. We used a propensity score matching approach to examine whether 3 weeks of students? game play was associated with increases in 4-year college planning, college-going aspirations, and educational aspirations from fall to spring. Our results showed that I2W users were about 18 percentage points more likely to have plans to attend a 4-year college compared to non-users if all students were randomly assigned to use I2W. In addition, I2W users were about 7 percentage points more likely to have college-going aspirations than non-users, after the propensity score adjustment. Second, we also found that I2W users were more likely to have a 4-year college plan in the spring by 15 percentage points compared to the estimates of similar students if they did not play I2W. Finally, data analyses reveal that I2W users increase their educational aspirations from fall to spring by .19 points compared to non-users. 

Our findings affirm that mobile technology is a critical tool for enhancing college and career readiness and we have published several journal articles that support this stance: 1) college and career knowledge is influenced by student friendship networks and varies among urban and rural communities (Chen, Spicer, & Schneider, 2020); 2) students who play I2W increase their college and career alignment knowledge in comparison to those who are unaligned players (Chen, Rocha-Beverly, & Schneider, 2020); and 3) I2W users have higher 4-year college plans, college-going aspirations and improvement of educational aspirations in contrast to nonplayers (Chen, Rocha-Beverly, & Schneider, 2020).

Two I2W concept papers were presented at the Midwest Sociology Conference and received excellent feedback for further prototype iterations.  Additional I2W manscripts were accepted for conference presentations at the American Education Research Association, the Society for Research on Educational Effectiveness, and the International Conference on Meaningful Play.  The I2W prototype was accepted for additional beta-testing through the Character Lab Research Network, which has access to hundreds of thousands of potential participants across the United States.

The value of the I2W game is that this thought-provoking but personalized tunnel exploration can result in virtually thousands of different outcomes and, ultimately, learning experiences about an imminent but often confusing process in postsecondary planning for low-income and Minority students. navigating life after high school.  To that end, the I2W mobile app may be the first educational, college/career preparatory mobile application with a game design to enter mainstream education markets.
